title: New vs Old Tax Regime: How to Choose the Best One in 2025-26?
excerpt: Get zero tax up to ₹12.75 lakh after Union Budget 2025! While the New Regime is now the default, learn why the Old Regime might still be the smarter choice for you.
content:
Every year as tax season approaches, the biggest question on every taxpayer's mind is: "Should I stick with the Old Tax Regime or switch to the New Tax Regime?" With major changes in Union Budget 2025, the New Tax Regime has become even more attractive—it’s now the default option, offering zero tax up to ₹12 lakh income (₹12.75 lakh for salaried with standard deduction). But it’s not the best choice for everyone. Let’s break it down in simple terms so you can save the maximum tax this year.

1. New Tax Regime: The Simple & Lower Rate Option

The New Regime was introduced to simplify taxation. It offers lower tax rates, but you forgo most deductions like 80C, HRA, and home loan interest. It’s ideal for those who want to avoid the hassle of investment proofs and paperwork.

  • Standard Deduction: ₹75,000 for salaried individuals.
  • Tax-Free Income: Zero tax up to ₹12 lakh; effectively ₹12.75 lakh with standard deduction.
  • New Tax Slabs (FY 2025-26):
    • ₹0 - ₹4 lakh: 0%
    • ₹4 - ₹8 lakh: 5%
    • ₹8 - ₹12 lakh: 10%
    • ₹12 - ₹16 lakh: 15%
    • ₹16 - ₹20 lakh: 20%
    • ₹20 - ₹24 lakh: 25%
    • Above ₹24 lakh: 30%

2. Old Tax Regime: Great for Investors

The Old Regime has higher rates but allows multiple deductions such as Section 80C, 80D, HRA, and home loan interest. It’s beneficial for those with home loans or heavy insurance investments.

3. Which is Better?

If total deductions (80C + 80D + HRA) are less than ₹6-8 lakh, the New Regime saves more. For high incomes with substantial deductions, the Old Regime can still be more advantageous.

title: E-Way Bill Expiry and Penalties in 2025: Avoid Heavy Fines with These Critical Tips
excerpt: E-way bill validity expiry can lead to severe penalties under GST, including fines up to 200%. Learn how to extend validity and special rules for gold jewellery to stay compliant.
content:
Transporting goods under GST without a valid e-way bill is a serious offence that can result in heavy penalties, vehicle detention, and business disruptions. In 2025, with real-time tracking via RFID and toll data, many businesses face unexpected checks leading to fines reaching 200% of the tax amount.

1. E-Way Bill Validity Rules in 2025

E-way bill validity is calculated based on distance. Standard rules for 2025:

  • Up to 200 km: 1 day
  • Additional 200 km: +1 day

2. Penalty for Expired E-Way Bill

Moving goods with an expired e-way bill is treated as transportation without valid documents. Penalties can be as high as 200% of the tax payable. Real-time monitoring in 2025 makes evasion harder and checks more frequent.

3. E-Way Bill Validity Extension

You can extend validity within 8 hours before or after expiry. Login to the portal, select 'Extend Validity', and provide reasons like traffic or breakdown.

4. Special Rules for Gold Jewellery

Gold and precious metals (Chapter 71) require e-way bills for movements above ₹50,000 inter-state. Use the 'EWB for Gold' option on the portal for extra security (no vehicle details needed).

Conclusion

E-way bill expiry can turn a routine transport into a nightmare. Stay vigilant with extensions and special gold rules to protect your business.
